Qsub: Single Function Submission¶

class clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub(target, args, n_nodes=1, n_cores=1, set_walltime='1:00:00', set_memory='8GB', set_cpu='1:00:00', wait_time=1, verbose=0)[source]¶

Bases: object

__add__(job)[source]¶

Adds two jobs together to create a QSession job

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> sess = q1 + q2
__and__(job)[source]¶

Adds two jobs together to create a QSession job

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> sess = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> sess += q

Note

Equivalent to __add__ or q1 + q2

__contains__(fnc)[source]¶

Boolean function for whether a function is contained within a job

Parameters:fnc (Python function) – function to find
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> job in q
True
__eq__(job)[source]¶

Returns whether the job’s walltime is equal to the other job’s walltime

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 == q2

Note

It will take almost a second to run when update_qstat_on_comparison is True since it checks and parses qstat -f. To make this run faster based on a previous qstat update, set update_qstat_on_comparison to False.

__ge__(job)[source]¶

Returns whether the job’s walltime is greater than or equal to the other job’s walltime

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 >= q2

Note

It will take almost a second to run when update_qstat_on_comparison is True since it checks and parses qstat -f. To make this run faster based on a previous qstat update, set update_qstat_on_comparison to False.

Returns whether the job’s walltime is greater than the other job’s walltime

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 > q2

Note

It will take almost a second to run when update_qstat_on_comparison is True since it checks and parses qstat -f. To make this run faster based on a previous qstat update, set update_qstat_on_comparison to False.

__le__(job)[source]¶

Returns whether the job’s walltime is less than the other job’s walltime

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 <= q2

Note

It will take almost a second to run when update_qstat_on_comparison is True since it checks and parses qstat -f. To make this run faster based on a previous qstat update, set update_qstat_on_comparison to False.

__lt__(job)[source]¶

Returns whether the job’s walltime is less than the other job’s walltime

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 < q2

Note

It will take almost a second to run when update_qstat_on_comparison is True since it checks and parses qstat -f. To make this run faster based on a previous qstat update, set update_qstat_on_comparison to False.

__mul__(n)[source]¶

Creates a QSession of multiple instances of the target function and args.

Parameters:n (int) – The number of instances
Returns:clusterweb.pbs.qsession.QSession
Example: 
>>> job = lambda z: meaning_to_life(z)
>>> q = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> sess = q * 5
>>> sess.push()
>>> sess.pull()
>>> sess.results
[42,42,42,42,42]
__ne__(job)[source]¶

Returns whether the job’s function is not equal to the function of another job.

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 == q2
False
>>> q3 = Qsub(job2,arg)
>>> q1 != q3
True
__or__(job)[source]¶

Adds two jobs together to create a QSession job

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> sess = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> sess += q

Note

Equivalent to __add__ or q1 + q2

allocate_cores(n_cores)[source]¶
allocate_memory(memory)[source]¶

Set the amount of memory for the job

Parameters:memory (str, int, float) – string in format ‘10GB’ or ‘500MB’ or number of MB

Example: >>> # Use three GB >>> qsub_job.allocate_memory(‘3GB’) >>> qsub_job.allocate_memory(3000) >>> >>> qsub_job.start()

allocate_nodes(n_nodes)[source]¶

Sets the number of nodes to a job submission.

allocate_walltime(walltime)[source]¶

Sets the amount of walltime

Will raise exception if str argument is not in the form hr:min:sec

Parameters:walltime (str, int, float) – amount of walltime in seconds
Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q.allocate_walltime('0:05:00') # Five minutes
>>> q.allocate_walltime(600) # Ten minutes
>>> q.allocate_walltime(599.6) # Rounds to ten minutes

Note

The walltime configuration can be adjusted by admins in clusterweb/pbs/config.py.

Warning

If users adjust clusterweb/pbs/config.py to settings not authorized by cluster admins, it will raise errors on the cluster and the job will not be submitted.

change_default_address(address)[source]¶

Change the default SSH address stored in username.txt which Qsub automatically sets itself to unless qsub.login is used.

Parameters:address (str) – Address or name for ssh to
Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q.change_default_address('192.168.1.24')
cleanup()[source]¶

Remove the temprorary folder that holds the compressed data and scripts that are sent to the cluster

Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,args)
>>> q.cleanup()

Note

This is automatically run and is not required to be run by the user.

create_timer(n_seconds)[source]¶

Create a timer that terminates the job if it exceeds the max time

Parameters:n_seconds (int, float) – The number of seconds for the timer, (n_seconds) > 0
Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,args)
>>> q.create_timer(600)

Note

This is a timer for the time since it was submitted, not for walltime.

fetch_result()[source]¶

Get the result of the job from the remote cluster synchronously with the main script.

Will continually check to see if the result file exists given a time interval self.wait_time. If it is a longer job, increase the wait time so as to not needless be calling SSH too many times.

Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,args)
>>> q.push()
>>> q.fetch_result()

Note

This is equivalent to pull(thread=False)

generate_qsub_script()[source]¶

Return the PBS submission script from the specified resource allocations.

Returns:None
is_(job)[source]¶

Returns whether the job’s walltime is equal to the other job’s walltime

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 is q2
True

Note

Equivalent to __eq_-

is_not(job)[source]¶

Returns whether the job’s function is not equal to the function of another job.

Parameters:job (clusterweb.pbs.qsub.Qsub) – Job to be compared to
Returns:True or False
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q2 = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q1 is not q2
False
>>> q3 = Qsub(job2,arg)
>>> q1 is not q3
True

Note

Equivalent to __ne__

login(address)[source]¶

Creates an SSH interface object with the address specified

Parameters:address (str) – Address or name for ssh to
Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,arg)
>>> q.login('192.168.1.42')

Note

The default address is contained in clusterweb/pbs/username.txt and can be adjusted with change_default_address

pull(thread=True, daemon=False)[source]¶

Get the result of the job from the remote cluster asynchronously with the main script.

Will continually check to see if the result file exists given a time interval self.wait_time. If it is a longer job, increase the wait time so as to not needless be calling SSH too many times.

Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,args)
>>> q.push()
>>> q.fetch_result()
push()[source]¶

Push the job to the remote cluster

Serializes the function, arguments, and send the generated scripts to the server. It automatically sends the PBS commands so this is the only command required to start the job on the cluster.

Resource allocation must occur before push is called.

Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q = Qsub(job,args)
>>> q.push()
quit()[source]¶
set_priority(priority)[source]¶

Set the priority of the job, default is 0

Parameters:priority (int (-1024,1023)) – The level of priority
Returns:None
Example: 
>>> q1 = Qsub(important_job,args)
>>> q1.set_priority(1000)
>>> 
>>> q2 = Qsub(not_so_important_job,args)
>>> q2.set_priority(-100)
update_qstat()[source]¶

Get the current data about a job from qstat

Parameters:
  • job_id (str) – The job id given by qsub
  • user (str) – The user id
Returns:

None

Note

Must be run after a job is submitted as qstat will only report data if it is in the queue
